lessons.title: Present Perfect Tense
lessons.explanation: The present perfect tense connects the past with the present. It's formed using 'have/has' + past participle. Use it for actions that started in the past and continue to the present, or for past actions with present relevance.
examples: I have lived in this city for five years.
She has finished her homework.
They have never been to Paris.
rules: Use 'have' with I, you, we, they
Use 'has' with he, she, it
Add 'not' after have/has for negative sentences
Move have/has to the beginning for questions

questions.question: Which sentence uses present perfect correctly?
options: I have went to the store yesterday.
I have gone to the store yesterday.
I have gone to the store many times.
I have go to the store many times.
questions.explanation: Present perfect uses 'have/has + past participle'. 'Gone' is the past participle of 'go'. Also, present perfect is not used with specific past time references like 'yesterday'.

questions.question: Complete the sentence: 'She ___ in London since 2018.'
questions.explanation: 'Since 2018' indicates an action that started in the past and continues to the present, which requires present perfect tense.

lessons.title: Conditional Sentences (Type 1)
lessons.explanation: First conditional sentences express real possibilities in the future. The structure is: If + present simple, will + base verb. These sentences describe situations that are likely to happen if a certain condition is met.
examples: If it rains tomorrow, we will stay indoors.
If you study hard, you will pass the exam.
She will be happy if you call her.
rules: Use present simple in the 'if' clause
Use 'will + base verb' in the main clause
Can reverse the order: 'We will stay indoors if it rains'
Can use other modals instead of 'will' (might, could, should)

questions.question: Which sentence shows correct first conditional structure?
options: If I will have time, I visit you.
If I have time, I will visit you.
If I had time, I will visit you.
If I have time, I would visit you.
questions.explanation: First conditional uses present simple in the 'if' clause and 'will + base verb' in the main clause.

questions.question: Complete: 'If the weather ___ nice, we ___ to the beach.'
questions.explanation: First conditional requires present simple ('is') in the if-clause and 'will + base verb' ('will go') in the main clause.

lessons.title: Passive Voice
lessons.explanation: Passive voice is used when the focus is on the action or the object receiving the action, rather than who performs the action. It's formed with 'be' + past participle. The person doing the action (agent) can be mentioned with 'by' or omitted entirely.
examples: The book was written by Shakespeare. (focus on the book)
The house is being painted. (agent not important)
English is spoken worldwide. (general truth)
rules: Use appropriate form of 'be' + past participle
The object of active sentence becomes subject of passive
Add 'by + agent' if the doer is important
Common in formal writing and when agent is unknown

questions.question: Convert to passive: 'Someone stole my bike.'
questions.explanation: Passive voice uses 'be + past participle'. Since the active sentence is in past simple, we use 'was stolen'.

questions.question: Which sentence is in passive voice?
options: Dinner is being cooked by the chef.
questions.explanation: Passive voice uses 'be + past participle'. 'Is being cooked' shows present continuous passive voice.

lessons.title: Simple Past Tense
lessons.explanation: The simple past tense is used for actions that happened at a specific time in the past. Regular verbs add '-ed'; irregular verbs have unique forms.
examples: She visited her grandmother yesterday.
They went to the park last week.
I finished my homework.
rules: Add '-ed' to regular verbs.
Irregular verbs have unique past forms.
Use time expressions like 'yesterday', 'last week', 'in 2010'.

questions.question: Which sentence uses simple past correctly?
questions.explanation: Simple past uses the verb + '-ed' for regular verbs.

questions.question: What is the past tense of 'go'?
questions.explanation: 'Went' is the past tense of 'go'.

lessons.title: Future Tense (Will)
lessons.explanation: The future tense with 'will' is used to talk about actions that will happen in the future. The structure is: will + base verb.
examples: I will call you tomorrow.
She will travel to London next month.
We will start the meeting at 10 AM.
rules: Use 'will' + base verb.
Use for predictions, promises, and decisions made at the moment.

questions.question: Choose the correct future tense sentence.
questions.explanation: Future tense uses 'will' + base verb.

questions.question: Which word completes: 'She ___ finish her work soon.'
questions.explanation: 'Will' is used for future actions.

lessons.title: Modal Verbs (Can, Could, Must)
lessons.explanation: Modal verbs express ability, possibility, necessity, or permission. Common modals are can, could, must, may, might, should, would.
examples: She can swim.
You must wear a seatbelt.
Could you help me?
rules: Modals are followed by the base verb.
Do not add 's', 'ed', or 'ing' to modals.
Use 'can' for ability, 'must' for necessity, 'could' for polite requests or past ability.

questions.question: Which sentence uses a modal verb correctly?
questions.explanation: Modals are followed by the base verb.

questions.question: Which modal expresses necessity?
questions.explanation: 'Must' expresses necessity.

lessons.title: Articles (A, An, The)
lessons.explanation: Articles are used before nouns. 'A' and 'an' are indefinite articles; 'the' is definite. Use 'a' before consonant sounds, 'an' before vowel sounds.
examples: I saw a dog.
She is an engineer.
The sun rises in the east.
rules: Use 'a' before consonant sounds.
Use 'an' before vowel sounds.
Use 'the' for specific nouns.

questions.question: Which article completes: 'He is ___ honest man.'
questions.explanation: 'An' is used before vowel sounds like 'honest'.

questions.question: Choose the correct sentence.
questions.explanation: 'A' is used before consonant sounds.

lessons.title: Reported Speech
lessons.explanation: Reported speech is used to tell what someone else said. Change the tense, pronouns, and time expressions as needed.
examples: She said that she was tired.
He told me he would help.
They asked if I could come.
rules: Change present to past tense.
Change pronouns and time expressions.
Use 'that' after reporting verbs.

questions.question: Change to reported speech: 'I am happy,' she said.
options: She said that she is happy.
questions.explanation: Change present to past tense in reported speech.

questions.question: Which is correct reported speech?
questions.explanation: 'Will' changes to 'would' in reported speech.

lessons.title: Adjectives and Adverbs
lessons.explanation: Adjectives describe nouns; adverbs describe verbs, adjectives, or other adverbs. Adverbs often end in '-ly'.
examples: She is a quick runner.
He ran quickly.
The very tall man smiled.
rules: Adjectives modify nouns.
Adverbs modify verbs, adjectives, or other adverbs.
Many adverbs end in '-ly'.

questions.question: Which word is an adverb?
questions.explanation: 'Quickly' is an adverb.

questions.question: Choose the correct sentence.
questions.explanation: 'She runs quickly.' is correct.

lessons.title: Prepositions of Place
lessons.explanation: Prepositions of place show where something is. Common prepositions are in, on, at, under, behind, between, next to.
examples: The book is on the table.
She sat between her friends.
The cat is under the chair.
rules: Use 'in' for enclosed spaces.
Use 'on' for surfaces.
Use 'at' for specific points.

questions.question: Which preposition completes: 'The cat is ___ the box.'
questions.explanation: 'In' is used for enclosed spaces.

questions.question: Choose the correct sentence.
questions.explanation: 'At' is used for specific points.
